newsitem.title: JAPAN: INTERVIEW - Ube eyes new magnesium technology.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Ube eyes new magnesium technology.

text.p: TOKYO, June 26, Reuter - Ube Industries Ltd, a manufacturer of chemicals and machinery, is eyeing a new technology that might persuade Japan's car and electronics industry to boost the use of magnesium.

"Now we are all (the industry) looking at the technology of thixo-moulding, though it's still uncertain how good it is," Tameyo Miki, general manager of Ube's light metal sales department, told Reuters in a recent interview.
"This technology might help the industry overcome one of the hurdles hindering the use of magnesium in this country."
Thixo-moulding, a possible alternative to diecasting, allows magnesium to be shaped without using strong heat to melt the metal, which is easily oxidised and set on fire.

In addition to its high price, difficulties involved in handling the metal, which is also used in fireworks to produce white-coloured sparks, are one of the major reasons behind the Japanese industry's reluctance to expand its use, Miki said.
Magnesium, lighter than aluminium but about twice as expensive, can be used to make lightweight components for cars.
Miki said the thixo-moulding technology, which was originally developed in the United States, could dramatically boost magnesium usage in Japan.
Data compiled by Toyota Motor Corp shows Japanese cars contain about 0.25 kg of magnesium each, compared to more than 1.5 kg in the U.S.

Japan's automobile industry is lagging far behind overseas counterparts in terms of magnesium usage. General Motors, Ford Motor Co and Volkswagen AG, have all invested in magnesium-production projects to secure a source of long-term supplies at the best price.
Official data shows that diecast magnesium, used mainly by the car industry, accounts for less than 10 percent of Japan's total magnesium demand of some 30,000 tonnes a year.
However Ube Industries, which launched a $8 million magnesium project in China after Japan stopped producing the metal in 1995, is confident the tide will change.
Full production at Ube's 4,000 tonne-per-year plant in China started this year.
"Japanese carmakers are about to review their policy (on magnesium)," Miki said. "Once the car industry does decide to go ahead with magnesium, the amount at stake is large."
Interest in the metal is also growing among makers of home electronics as magnesium is easy to recycle and shields electro-magnetic waves, he said.

Resin processors in particular are examining thixo-moulding technology carefully as electronics companies, such as Sony Corp, have already started using magnesium in cases for video cameras, mobile telephones, portable music systems and lap-top computers, he said.

Asked whether Ube was considering a second plant in China, Miki said: "In the long term, there will be insufficient production, especially of magnesium alloy. At one point, we have to start thinking about it."
